home.title: Nes HaTamar
home.subtitle: A Journey Through the Paths of Our Sacred Torah to the World of Homeopathy and Medicinal Plants
home.description: Nes HaTamar is a rare fusion of spiritual and material worlds, faith and medicine. It is a soulful journey inviting the reader to know the Healer of all flesh and the life force inherent in humanity.
home.journey: Like a walk through an enchanted garden, the book unveils a rich world of plants, animals, minerals, and metals, revealing the hidden healing powers that operate according to the law of similars: like cures like.
home.connection: This is a pioneering work connecting the Torah of Israel with the world of homeopathy and medicinal plants. The book illuminates how true healing does not merely cover symptoms but touches the root of illness and sweetens its cause.
home.experience: Accompanied by ancient and modern artwork, Nes HaTamar is an experience that engages all senses - internal and external - and opens a new dialogue between the supernatural world of miracles and the natural world itself, between the bitterness of illness and the sweetness of the date palm.

tamar.name: Tamar Eshel
tamar.bio: A lawyer by training, but her heart is devoted to the world of kindness and natural medicine. She studied homeopathy at the school of Yosef Reves, the father of homeopathy in Israel, and for over two decades has been practicing homeopathy and the connection between body, soul, and faith. A graduate of Rabbi Yitzchak Ginsburgh's School of the Soul, drawing her inspiration primarily from Chabad Chassidic writings. She studies and teaches Torah and Chassidus. Her previous book 'A Feminine Journey Through the Omer Count' has inspired many women.

nissim.name: Nissim Krispil
nissim.bio: A writer, researcher, and anthropologist, one of the pioneers in the field of ethnobotany in Israel. For decades, he has been documenting the healing traditions, faith, and culture of Jewish and folk communities in Israel and around the world. His books, dealing with medicinal plants, foraging, folklore, and ethnography, have become milestones in Israeli research and culture. The crown jewel among them is the comprehensive encyclopedia 'Yalkut HaTzemaḥim' (The Plant Collection). Alongside his research work, Nissim also engages in poetry and music, seeing nature and humanity as one complete unity, seeking to connect body and soul, science and faith, earth and spirit.
